to start with why you need a recovery plan if I can convince you that you do
need one then we'll get into the elements of what should be in it going
into details of what you need to backup and why and finally we're going to wrap up with a survey of existing tools that
will help you do backups and recoveries when running on kubernetes and we're
going to close with a demo of one of those tools first to start out why you
need a recovery plan well people are obviously aware that hardware is never perfect and machines and software fail
in my experience working in the backup field actually people like to blame the
hardware but the actual statistics tend to tell you that most of the really ugly scenarios are based on human error where
people make mistakes you've also got exposure to weather terrorism crime
earthquakes a long list depending on your industry many industries are also
faced with conducting backup simply because regulations require them to
retain data for certain of years so the same thing you would do
the same backups that satisfy legal requirements for data retention can be a
part of your backup recovery plan there's a lot of elements of a disaster
recovery plan you know it isn't all about backups you need to plan for you
know in the event of a physical disaster you need to have made prior arrangements
for replacement Hardware or a replacement public cloud hosting so that
you can attempt to stand it up at your recovery site you also need planning you don't wait until your system is your
data center is on fire and then decide what do we need to get this thing back on the air a plan in one person's head
isn't good enough you're going to have to have people who can carry out whatever you've listed in that plan and
finally those people need to be training trained and they need to practice it's
not enough just to make the plan it has to be a living document I've I've heard
of places that write this plan have the disaster five years later and discover that so much has changed that it no
longer is a viable plan and it's not enough to document it and keep it on the
data set or infrastructure you're trying to replace there's a few ugly stories of
people who had an elaborate back-up plan but then they've lost power lost the
data center and they no longer have access to it it it might be a good idea
to actually physically print this out with multiple copies so then you're guaranteed to have access to it or to
keep it on standalone tablets tablets are perhaps a little more high-tech than
printouts because you can do things like have checklists as you go through a process to try to eliminate mistakes and
that is one thing that I believe the airline industry does now where the pilots with most commercial airlines
keep plans on tablets that the pilots routinely practice with what do you want
to protect well it's Theory all data cuber Nettie's objects are stored in the
sed database so periodically backing up the sed cluster is important so that you
can recover a kubernetes cluster and this this statement I'm not making it up
it's in the kubernetes Doc's the sed database also was used to hold state for
some of some popular Network plugins not all there are you know the network
infrastructure and kubernetes is a plugin so there some of those plugins choose to retain their configuration
stayed outside fcd but many of them are using SED the modern trend of extending
kubernetes with CR DS is generally going to hold the state associated with those CR DS in sed but there is critical state
that isn't in at CD so at CD isn't going to be enough if you have a Total Wipeout of a data center some things that live
outside at CD persistent volumes so if you're running containerized databases
they use persistent volume mouths the content of those volumes is often is
generally going to be large and obviously not in the at CD key value store kubernetes has widespread use of
certificates and key pairs certificate authorities and if you wipe everything out if you really want to get a restore
and have remote clients attach and get authenticated you're going to have to
restore those certificates so it's a good idea to keep backups of those available there are also often going to
be service accounts where kubernetes is running on underlying infrastructure and that underlying infrastructure or that
public cloud is likely to have credentials associated with it you've
got if you have C RDS and CI a plugins not using sed you need to figure out
where that state lives and cover it often you're dependent on physical networking infrastructure things like
configuring DNS rough records of routing I assignments and if you do a rebuild from
scratch you want to record those things so that they can be recovered likewise
if you're running on a cloud a public cloud or private infrastructure there's
very likely to be a bunch of account and configuration status and credentials for
that redundancy alone is not enough if you there are many whose first impression is
that hey I'm running a three node at CD cluster if I lose one of those nodes inherently Etsy didn't go down but like
I said earlier the hardware failure isn't the only thing you're protecting against in a human error scenario if
someone deletes an object and discovers this five minutes later that change will
have been replicated more or less immediately to all three nodes of your red CD so you're not going to be able to
roll it back you know simple mirroring of what the state is now on multiple
things only protects against a subset of the failures you're potentially exposed to other things to consider in the
realities of your stateful apps are that even your stateless apps is that these
things are based on container images now a rookie mistake might be to be
downloading those from docker hub shooting them right into production but more than likely you're running some
sort of private container registry and if you're recovering from a disaster
you don't want to go figure out what used to be in the old one that's now gone and even if you did have a list of
what images are supposed to be in there it might take a long time to get those
things restored and even if you pointed to docker images with particularly
Buhl's if you're familiar with how that works there's no guarantee that the one you had before is actually identical to
what's out there with the same label right now there are you can put things in docker hub with pretty loose labeling
you're not supposed to do it but labels like latest and whatever and end up with something
reproducible so I'd suggest you that there are container image registries
that are out there capable of replication so that you can replicate
them to an outside failure domain maybe even to another image repository in a
cloud or at a distant location and then count on the replication in the opposite
direction to bring things back the way they were originally helm can helm
charts and maybe other binaries fall into that same category it may not even
be a bad idea to backup any things associated with your hardware like I
don't know that base images for os's maybe even going so far as firmware
updates in case you have replacement Hardware that might be sitting there acquired two years ago and not have been
getting updates you know if you have local caches of that you maintain every
time you download for production put it in some sort of storage so that if you
have to do a recovery or acquire replacement Hardware that this stuff is
restorable to the appropriate conditions you know there been stories of people who were running some BAC level hardware
that was no longer out there so they end up buying replacements off eBay and there's no telling what kind of firmware
updates those might need and it might be a good idea to set aside storage to hold those kinds of things so reconsider a
recovery solution for your registries and maybe replication is a part of that
